query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 «Poscia che Costantin l’aquila volse 2 contr’ al corso del ciel, ch’ella seguio 3 dietro a l’antico che Lavina tolse,
4 cento e cent’ anni e più l’uccel di Dio 5 ne lo stremo d’Europa si ritenne, 6 vicino a’ monti de’ quai prima uscìo;
7 e sotto l’ombra de le sacre penne 8 governò ’l mondo lì di mano in mano, 9 e, sì cangiando, in su la mia pervenne.

Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Cesare fui e son Iustinïano, 11 che, per voler del primo amor ch’i’ sento, 12 d’entro le leggi trassi il troppo e ’l vano.
query.result: 10 Caesar I was and am Justinian, 11 who, by the will of the first love that I feel, 12 from within the laws drew out the excessive and the vain.

13 And before I was attentive to the work, 14 a nature in Christ to be, no more, 15 I believed, and with such faith was content;
16 but the blessed Agapito, who was 17 supreme shepherd, to the sincere faith 18 straightened me with his words.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Io li credetti; e ciò che ’n sua fede era, 20 vegg’ io or chiaro sì, come tu vedi 21 ogni contradizione e falsa e vera.
query.result: 19 I believed him; and what was in his faith, 20 I see now clear, as you see 21 every contradiction, false and true.

22 Quickly that with the Church I moved the feet, 23 to God by grace it pleased to inspire me 24 the high work, and all in him I gave myself;
25 and to my Belisarius I commended the arms, 26 to whom the right hand of heaven was so joined, 27 that it was a sign that I should rest myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Or qui a la question prima s’appunta 29 la mia risposta; ma sua condizione 30 mi stringe a seguitare alcuna giunta,
31 perché tu veggi con quanta ragione 32 si move contr’ al sacrosanto segno 33 e chi ’l s’appropria e chi a lui s’oppone.
query.result:
28 Now here to the first question is pointed 29 my answer; but its condition 30 constrains me to follow some addition,
31 because you see with how much reason 32 it moves against the most sacred sign 33 and who appropriates it and who opposes it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Vedi quanta virtù l’ha fatto degno 35 di reverenza; e cominciò da l’ora 36 che Pallante morì per darli regno.
query.result: 34 See how much virtue has made him worthy 35 of reverence; and it began from the hour 36 that Pallante died to give him kingdom.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Tu sai ch’el fece in Alba sua dimora 38 per trecento anni e oltre, infino al fine 39 che i tre a’ tre pugnar per lui ancora.
query.result: 37 You know that he made his dwelling in Alba 38 for three hundred years and more, until the end 39 that the three at three fought for him still.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 E sai ch’el fé dal mal de le Sabine 41 al dolor di Lucrezia in sette regi, 42 vincendo intorno le genti vicine.
query.result: 40 And you know that he made from the harm of the Sabines 41 to the pain of Lucretia in seven kings, 42 conquering around the neighboring peoples.

43 You know what he made carried by the excellent 44 Romans against Brennus, against Pyrrhus, 45 against the other princes and colleges;
46 whence Torquatus and Quinzio, who from the curl 47 neglected was named, the Decii and the Fabii 48 had the fame that I gladly admire.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Esso atterrò l’orgoglio de li Aràbi 50 che di retro ad Anibale passaro 51 l’alpestre rocce, Po, di che tu labi.
query.result: 49 He struck down the pride of the Arabs 50 who behind Hannibal passed 51 the alpine rocks, Po, of which you read.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Sott’ esso giovanetti trïunfaro 53 Scipïone e Pompeo; e a quel colle 54 sotto ’l qual tu nascesti parve amaro.
query.result: 52 Under it young men triumphed 53 Scipio and Pompey; and to that hill 54 under which you were born, it seemed bitter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Poi, presso al tempo che tutto ’l ciel volle 56 redur lo mondo a suo modo sereno, 57 Cesare per voler di Roma il tolle.
query.result: 55 Then, near the time that all the heaven willed 56 to reduce the world to its serene manner, 57 Caesar, by the will of Rome, takes it away.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 E quel che fé da Varo infino a Reno, 59 Isara vide ed Era e vide Senna 60 e ogne valle onde Rodano è pieno.
query.result: 58 And what he did from Var to the Rhine, 59 Isara saw and Era and saw the Seine 60 and every valley where the Rhone is full.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Quel che fé poi ch’elli uscì di Ravenna 62 e saltò Rubicon, fu di tal volo, 63 che nol seguiteria lingua né penna.
query.result: 61 What he did then after he exited Ravenna 62 and jumped the Rubicon, was of such flight, 63 that no tongue nor pen would follow it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Inver’ la Spagna rivolse lo stuolo, 65 poi ver’ Durazzo, e Farsalia percosse 66 sì ch’al Nil caldo si sentì del duolo.
query.result: 64 He turned the flock towards Spain, 65 then towards Durazzo, and struck at Pharsalia 66 so that at the hot Nile, the sorrow was felt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Antandro e Simeonta, onde si mosse, 68 rivide e là dov’ Ettore si cuba; 69 e mal per Tolomeo poscia si scosse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Da indi scese folgorando a Iuba; 71 onde si volse nel vostro occidente, 72 ove sentia la pompeana tuba.

Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Di quel che fé col baiulo seguente, 74 Bruto con Cassio ne l’inferno latra, 75 e Modena e Perugia fu dolente.
query.result: 73 Of what he did with the following standard-bearer, 74 Brutus with Cassius barks in hell, 75 and Modena and Perugia were sorrowful.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Piangene ancor la trista Cleopatra, 77 che, fuggendoli innanzi, dal colubro 78 la morte prese subitana e atra.
query.result: 76 Still Cleopatra weeps for it, 77 who, fleeing from them ahead, from the snake 78 took sudden and dark death.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Con costui corse infino al lito rubro; 80 con costui puose il mondo in tanta pace, 81 che fu serrato a Giano il suo delubro.

Please translate each line literally into English.
82 Ma ciò che ’l segno che parlar mi face 83 fatto avea prima e poi era fatturo 84 per lo regno mortal ch’a lui soggiace,
85 diventa in apparenza poco e scuro, 86 se in mano al terzo Cesare si mira 87 con occhio chiaro e con affetto puro;
88 ché la viva giustizia che mi spira, 89 li concedette, in mano a quel ch’i’ dico, 90 gloria di far vendetta a la sua ira.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Or qui t’ammira in ciò ch’io ti replìco: 92 poscia con Tito a far vendetta corse 93 de la vendetta del peccato antico.
query.result: 91 Now here you admire in what I reply to you: 92 afterwards with Titus it ran to do vengeance 93 of the vengeance of the ancient sin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 E quando il dente longobardo morse 95 la Santa Chiesa, sotto le sue ali 96 Carlo Magno, vincendo, la soccorse.
query.result: 94 And when the Lombard tooth bit 95 the Holy Church, under its wings 96 Charles the Great, winning, aided it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Omai puoi giudicar di quei cotali 98 ch’io accusai di sopra e di lor falli, 99 che son cagion di tutti vostri mali.
query.result: 97 Now you can judge of those like that 98 whom I accused of above and of their faults, 99 who are cause of all your evils.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 L’uno al pubblico segno i gigli gialli 101 oppone, e l’altro appropria quello a parte, 102 sì ch’è forte a veder chi più si falli.
query.result: 100 One opposes the yellow lilies to the public sign, 101 and the other appropriates it to a part, 102 so that it is strong to see who errs more.

103 Let the Ghibellines do, let them do their art 104 under another sign, because evil follows that one 105 always who justice and him separates;
106 and let not this new Charles overthrow 107 with his Guelphs, but fear the claws 108 that to a higher lion drew the fleece.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Molte fïate già pianser li figli 110 per la colpa del padre, e non si creda 111 che Dio trasmuti l’armi per suoi gigli!
112 Questa picciola stella si correda 113 d’i buoni spirti che son stati attivi 114 perché onore e fama li succeda:
115 e quando li disiri poggian quivi, 116 sì disvïando, pur convien che i raggi 117 del vero amore in sù poggin men vivi.
query.result:
109 Many times already have the sons wept 110 for the fault of the father, and let it not be believed 111 that God transmutates the arms for his lilies!
112 This little star equips itself 113 with the good spirits that have been active 114 so that honor and fame may succeed them:
115 and when the desires rest there, 116 thus deviating, it must happen that the rays 117 of true love ascend less alive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Ma nel commensurar d’i nostri gaggi 119 col merto è parte di nostra letizia, 120 perché non li vedem minor né maggi.
query.result: 118 But in the commensuration of our hounds 119 with the merit is part of our joy, 120 because we do not see them lesser nor greater.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Quindi addolcisce la viva giustizia 122 in noi l’affetto sì, che non si puote 123 torcer già mai ad alcuna nequizia.
query.result: 121 Therefore living justice sweetens 122 in us the affection so that it cannot 123 ever be turned to any wickedness.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Diverse voci fanno dolci note; 125 così diversi scanni in nostra vita 126 rendon dolce armonia tra queste rote.

Please translate each line literally into English.
127 E dentro a la presente margarita 128 luce la luce di Romeo, di cui 129 fu l’ovra grande e bella mal gradita.
query.result: 127 And within the present pearl 128 shines the light of Romeo, of whom 129 was the great and beautiful work unwelcome.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Ma i Provenzai che fecer contra lui 131 non hanno riso; e però mal cammina 132 qual si fa danno del ben fare altrui.
query.result: 130 But the Provençals who made war against him 131 have not laughed; and therefore badly goes 132 whoever makes harm from doing good to others.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Quattro figlie ebbe, e ciascuna reina, 134 Ramondo Beringhiere, e ciò li fece 135 Romeo, persona umìle e peregrina.
query.result: 133 Four daughters he had, and each one a queen, 134 Ramondo Beringhiere, and this made him 135 Romeo, a humble and foreign person.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 E poi il mosser le parole biece 137 a dimandar ragione a questo giusto, 138 che li assegnò sette e cinque per diece,
139 indi partissi povero e vetusto; 140 e se ’l mondo sapesse il cor ch’elli ebbe 141 mendicando sua vita a frusto a frusto,
142 assai lo loda, e più lo loderebbe».
query.result:
136 And then they moved him the vile words 137 to ask reason to this just one, 138 who assigned to him seven and five for ten,
139 then he departed poor and aged; 140 and if the world knew the heart that he had 141 begging his life from lash to lash,
142 they would praise him much, and praise him more.
